body: Yeah, this is an outstanding work-item in our backlog to help users configure the CUDA EP from C#. We will get to it as soon as we can. Marked the issue as an enhancement.
@hariharands29 please also consider the root cause of onnxrt picking the wrong cudnn kernels... i guess sth is again wrong about cudnn benchmark setup / workspace...
@hariharans29 Understood. I will be waiting for the upcoming package. Until then, guess I will have to wait. Thank you for getting back.

@vadimkantorov: The root cause is this revert: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/8181. We found that the workspace memory could jump up by GBs when CuDNN is picking the best possible Conv algo. This did not play well with our allocator setup and this was a learning for us and we had to pull out that change that was prompted by your issue.

Subsequently, this change added it back: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/8613 but we had to gate the algo picking functionality as it seems with it turned on, it improves the perf of your models but causes regressions in some others. So, we need to expose the flag for users to turn it on while inferencing. You can set [this line](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/ac57afc3a69dfc6a57caeee678966a1fce50bca9/onnxruntime/core/providers/cuda/cuda_execution_provider.h#L85) to return true (by default it is returning false) and build from source if you need it for now. We need to prioritize the work-item to expose a to turn it on.

> @hariharans29 Understood. I will be waiting for the upcoming package. Until then, guess I will have to wait. Thank you for getting back.

@callbarian : The upcoming package is 2 weeks away but this feature will not make it into that. It might make it into one of the releases in the new year though based on other priorities. I will keep the issue open for tracking. FWIW: This is an implicit dupe of this issue: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/8995 as it is also about configuring the CUDA EP from C#.

It would be nice if you had added basic jaspernet conv1d models in your benchmarks, e.g. we had found earlier that 1.8.0 worked well, 1.8.1 already had a perf regression (I guess because of the revert)

@vadimkantorov: The regression in 1.8.1 was expected as we reverted the change because it caused a memory bloat (It wasn't missed due to lack of benchmarks). To re-introduce the change, we had to re-architect our memory allocation setup for CUDA. 

I just realized though, the flag to use the maximum possible workspace isn't available in C/C++/C# but it is available in Python as the provider options is just a map. See this:

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/7e207ba3be3620ffbb9f8b8fcffd15e911a744e3/orttraining/orttraining/python/training/ortmodule/_graph_execution_manager.py#L268

If you use Python, you could pass in the provider option to turn the feature ON. See this for an example on how to use the provider options map:

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/ac57afc3a69dfc6a57caeee678966a1fce50bca9/onnxruntime/test/python/onnxruntime_test_python.py#L154

issue.title: Enable CUDA provider option configuration for C#

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Description**: 

This is the CUDA EP equivalent of the PR https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/7808 (All the design choices have already been discussed there). 

This change makes the `OrtCUDAProviderOptions` struct opaque and supports setting options that can be converted to a string. Just like the TensorRT PR, an API to set options that can't be strings (`user_compute_stream` and `default_memory_arena_cfg`) is not yet supported and will be added incrementally. Since these are not very commonly used, it is okay to leave them unsupported for now. For users who still need them, they can still use the legacy struct and its corresponding ORT APIs.  

**Motivation and Context**
1) Enables basic configuration of the CUDA EP via C# (Resolves https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/9730 and https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/8995)

2) Introduces a new C API CUDA EP configuration - `cudnn_conv_use_max_workspace`. This was already available via Python but not available for C API users. This configuration is particularly important for fp16 Conv heavy models. See https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/9162 and https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/9916 for details as to why. By this reasoning, this PR should resolve this perf complaint - https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/9420. 

3) Addresses a backlog item to make the `OrtCUDAProviderOptions` opaque
